68.50.text:
>>SALLY MURPHY - First Female U.S. Army Helicopter Pilot:
I was selected in 1973 to begin the Army's initial entry rotary wing program

76.00.text: That is the first level of flight training for the United States Army

80.26.text: I served for 27 years in the Army

83.00.text: and during that 27 years I saw a magical transformation

87.00.text: I was at the beginning of what they called the great WAC expansion

91.00.text: which not only opened fields for women in aviation, eventually, but also women in all sorts of fields

97.00.text: The country had come to realize that their educated daughters were trained and raring to go

103.00.text: in fields that had never been open to them before

106.00.text: It was not too many years later that I saw some of these women

109.26.text: who had been trained in the military, in helicopters and airplanes

114.16.text: had left the service and were fleshing out the ranks of commercial aviation

119.60.text:
Now that's not to say that I'm old enough to remember the first woman who ever flew,
because I don't

125.16.text: Women have been flying for decades before I even thought of flying

129.33.text:
They had been flying for personal pleasure, flying for pay,
and they had flown in support of military operations

138.33.text:
It was, however, new that the Army was actively recruiting women
to join the Army first

144.33.text: to be soldiers, and then to be trained in aviation

148.33.text: Well, I'm credited sometimes for kicking that door

151.43.text:
But it's not so much I kicked down the door,
it was the fact that the Army deliberately opened the door

156.00.text: and I chose to walk through it

159.00.text:
I'm told that I diminish how important that was,
but to me it's just living life

164.00.text:
You take on a challenge and you either like it or don't like it,
then you take on another challenge

168.50.text:
It's getting up every morning, and going to work,
and doing the best you can

172.26.text:
and hoping that people realize you're doing the best you can,
and hoping it's good work

177.16.text: I never gave much serious thought to the fact that I was "blazing a trail"

182.00.text: but 27 years later, after many people told me I had done so

186.33.text:
I was able to look over my shoulder and realize that I was much more gratified
by seeing so many women who had followed that open door

194.50.text:
had even made it wider and chosen other doors 
to open in aviation fields that I had not even considered

202.00.text:
If I had gone down that path as the first,
but the only woman helicopter pilot in the Army

209.06.text: it would have been a bittersweet experience

212.00.text:
but as you'll see, there are women who have entered aviation not just as pilots,
but in other fields, other disciplines

220.06.text: and they have their very own stories to tell too

228.43.text:
My name is Melissa Mathiasen and I'm the chief pilot at Sikorsky Global Helicopters
in Coatesville, Pennsylvania

238.43.text:
Sikorsky Global Helicopters is primarily a completions center
for the S-76C++ and the S-92A

248.00.text:
They also are a production facility,
which means that we manufacture the S-76C++

255.00.text: and later this year we will put out our first S-92 that will be manufactured on site

261.43.text: In the flight office itself we support the completions and production schedule

267.16.text:
so if an aircraft is produced or manufactured here,
we do all of the initial ground runs and test flights for that aircraft

275.00.text:
making sure it's airworthy and that it meets all of the FAA requirements
and manufacturer requirements for those aircraft

281.00.text:
Then it goes into our completions center, and it's essentially outfitted with the interior,
the avionics package, the paint scheme that the customer wants

290.63.text: and any other special items that they want in the aircraft

294.43.text: My name is Stacy Sheard, I'm a production test pilot for Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation

301.50.text: Basically, we're flying helicopters for the first time they've ever been flown

306.16.text:
For the production line of helicopters, this is their first flight,
it might be the first time that the engines are running in the helicopter

314.43.text: so everything, as far as tests, we do it step by step

320.00.text:
As soon as everyone has signed off; all the mechanics, avionics technicians,
everybody involved with building that helicopter

327.00.text:
as soon as they've signed off that they're complete with their individual job,
and the helicopter is presented to us

333.33.text:
after it's been fully inspected, then we go through a series of checks
to make sure that everything inside the cockpit is working and operational

341.66.text: Then we pull it outside and do our first ground runs

346.26.text:
Once all the ground operations are done
and we're satisfied that the helicopter is safe and complete,
everything is working as it should

354.16.text: then it's time to commence the first flights

361.20.text: My name is Amelia Earhart, and I work here at Angel City Air

365.33.text:
I also work for CBS and sometimes KCAL,
who are two stations in a duopoly together

371.66.text:
My title is basically breaking news/aerial reporter
I sit in the back seat of the helicopter and I'm also the camera operator

380.43.text:
and I operate the HD Cineflex camera
that's mounted on the front of the chopper

385.70.text:
Basically, Kris and I fly as a team to any situation
whether it's traffic, breaking news, a weather shot

395.10.text: or just general morning news during the morning show

399.03.text:
we fly together as a team, Kris up front and me in the back seat
and we navigate our way to whatever is going on

404.60.text:
and I shoot it with the camera,
then I talk over that picture

408.63.text:
>>Kris Kelley, TV News Pilot:
Well I'm a helicopter pilot for CBS here in Los Angeles

415.60.text:
So that means I get up really early in the morning
because I fly for the morning show

421.36.text: and I fly around Amelia Earhart

425.13.text:
who is our camera operator as well as the talent
for the morning show, breaking news, and traffic

433.60.text: we do the morning show, Amelia and myself

434.00.text:
so my job is to fly Amelia around, do the breaking news
or whatever story we're covering that morning

445.33.text:
and we'll be out there and be first on scene
to get the coverage on the air

450.80.text:
My name is Mandy Haskins and I'm a flight paramedic
for Priority 1 Air Rescue

455.40.text:
being a flight medic, that means that we fly around in the helicopter
and do search and rescue missions

461.66.text: and pick up patients that are out in the field somewhere

465.80.text:
it's important in Alaska to have search and rescue helicopters
because we don't have road systems everywhere like they do in the other U.S. states

474.56.text: Our ability to hoist is a really good way to go in and get these people

482.10.text:
because we can go in and hover above their location,
then we can hoist down and lift them up in a harness or put them in our litter system

490.43.text:
we can start patient care on the ground
or we can start it in the helicopter

494.06.text:
>>Janie Foster - MEDEVAC Pilot:
Hoisting is a lot of fun, at first it was difficult when it was new

499.10.text:
however, it has become a lot of fun because it tasks us
with a challenge to maintain a very stable hover in one place

507.50.text: with references that are different from when you're on the ground

511.36.text:
near the ground you have a lot of visual references, but once you get high
and you no longer have trees, rocks, or other items to use as a reference

520.66.text:
or when we're over terrain that is falling away,
it does make quite a different challenge for holding a hover

529.03.text:
It takes a lot of concentration, and of course we have teamwork in the cockpit.
The pilot not flying is providing altitude and power information

538.36.text:
because we can't really look inside the helicopter,
we are focusing on our reference outside

547.40.text:
>>Teri Northcott - Owner of Resource Helicopters:
I own a helicopter company that primarily fights forest fires

555.20.text:
and my job is making sure that everybody is operating safely
and that our customer's needs are being met

563.00.text:
and that everybody  is operating within the regulations
that they're supposed to be

569.50.text: I don't really think there is such a thing as a "typical" day

575.70.text:
that's one of the things that's so interesting about this business,
it's so fast-paced and changing all the time

583.30.text:
just by the very nature of how a helicopter itself operates;
it doesn't operate within the confines of airports and runways, and those types of things

592.70.text:
I find that, overall, the business itself is very much like that.
So my days are not typical, one after the other

602.76.text:
they can start very early in the morning and go until very late in the evening
depending on what time zones my crews are working in

610.16.text:
then in the interim you do all of your normal day-to-day stuff
like banking and things like that, which you do throughout a normal work day

620.30.text:
So, the days can be very long and very full
but that's part of the appeal

626.63.text:
I'm Stacy Gandy, I'm an aviation maintenance technican
for Air Methods out of Denver, Colorado.

632.00.text:
I hold an airframe and powerplant license
and I'm also an air worthiness inspector for the FAA

639.10.text:
Basically, I'm called an on sight mechanic,
I'm here for this helicopter only; 24 hours, 7 days a week

648.36.text:
I generally work here about 5 hours a day doing inspections
and any maintenance I need to do.  After that I'm on call for the rest of the day

657.23.text:
The helicopter doesn't always break here. It might be in a field,
or someplace they have a hard time giving you directions to find

667.33.text:
It's kind of interesting because it's not standard
and you have to be very flexible

674.00.text:
My name is Heather Collins and my title is Registered Nurse/Flight Nurse
at AeroMed; I work for Tampa General Hospital

683.43.text:
I have worked for Tampa General since 1975
and with this flight program since 1989

691.63.text:
The duties here emcompass nursing care of the patient as well as
the aviation aspect of flight nursing

703.13.text:
A typical call will either be a "scene call" or an "interfacility".
A scene call is when we go to the site of an accident and pick up the patients

715.70.text: They will land us in a field or whatever is close by to the accident

720.66.text:
We'll recieve the patient from the paramedics who have cared for the patient on scene,
get report, do any interventions that might be necessary to stabilize the patient

730.20.text:
load them on our aircraft and take them to the nearest trauma center,
or stroke center or whatever the most appropirate place is for the patient

739.06.text:
My name is Caroline Caine, I'm a captain with Bristow Helicopters in Alaska.
I fly a Bell Helicopter 407, in a remote location on the north slope of the Brook's Range

750.36.text: I fly to pump station number 4 and it's located along the Trans-Alaska Pipeline

757.00.text: Working in a remote location, we only have about 40-45 people on site at pump 4

763.90.text:
Being in such a remote location, you really need to get along with the folks there,
otherwise it doesn't create a very fun work environment

771.40.text:
We're on a 2 week on, 2 week off work rotation. You can drive to pump 4
on the Dalton Highway or the "Haul Road" as it's called

779.30.text:
But that can take about 8 hours, so it wouldn't be a very good commute.
So Alyeska actually charters an airline, and we fly in every other Thursday

789.23.text:
Current pilot duties and responsibilities include: oil spill response,
weekly pipeline survelliance

796.73.text:
We do medevacs and external load operations and also air support
for the communication repeater sites

804.20.text:
Pump station 4 covers 208 miles of the pipeline
and we cover from pump station number 1 to mile post 208

814.23.text: So that's all in mile post miles, or pipeline miles

817.43.text:
The weekly survelliance that we do, we actually have a securtiy observer with us,
we'll fly about 300 feet off the ground at about 100 knots

826.50.text:
It's a lot a fun flying low like that. The observer will then look out the window,
check the integrity of the pipe and make sure there haven't been any changes

837.56.text:
My name is Sjaan Schoepf, I'm a seasonal contract pilot
for Bristow Alaska

843.26.text:
I have been up here two previous seasons and I
have also worked tours and I've done a little EMS

851.00.text:
but I think my passion is mostly in utility and especially
in precision long line work

858.80.text:
As a long line pilot you have what they call an external load,
so if you've ever seen a firefighting helicopter where there's a line that comes down below

868.66.text:
in firefighting you have a water bucket. You can use that same technique,
but instead of fighting fires with water, you can set air conditioning units on top of a roof

885.33.text:
Or you can do all sorts of different things.  In my case, mostly I've moved drills
for an exploration that's looking for coal

895.50.text:
and I move these drills that have different pieces and sections
which need to be stacked, and obviously they are too heavy for a person or two people to lift

906.36.text:
and they are in the remote locations of Alaska, so you can't haul in
heavy equipment and tear up the tundra, so we do it all by helicopter

916.63.text:
My name is Amy Sargent, I'm with the Florida Keys Mosquito Control,
I'm the chief pilot and we spray for mosquitos

924.56.text:
We both larvicide and adulticide, which means that we are killing both
mosquito larvae and adult mosquitos using helicopters and fixed wing aircraft

934.16.text:
When we larvacide we have a spray system that puts out a granular pellet,
which is actually ground up corn cob with a bacteria on it

945.30.text:
The mosquito larvae will eat the bacteria that comes off the ground up corn cob
and it causes their stomach lining to rupture, killing the mosquito larvae

956.63.text: To adulticide we use a liquid product that we spray out of the helicopter

964.30.text:
We have 11 pilots here at Mosquito Control, 7 of them are fixed-wing
and just part-time pilots, and 4 of us are helicopter pilots

977.50.text:
Our spray season normally runs from May to October, that's our busy season.
During the off season we do a lot of training

988.20.text:
Everything we do is low level, right over the tree tops, over wires, around towers.
I hate to use the term "type A" personality, but you do need to be a perfectionist

1001.03.text:
I think most pilots are, it's required. I shouldn't say it's required, it's a skill
that will help save your life, because you can't be wrong

1018.30.text:
When you start making mistakes, that chain of events is going to lead to an accident.
So you need to be a perfectionist and that's what we train for

1029.36.text:
>>Stacy Gandy:
Helicopters are like thousands of little serial numbers that fly around together,
every one of these components has to be tracked

1038.40.text:
People don't realize how safe helicopters are because of that very reason,
every component has a time life and an overhaul time

1049.13.text:
This makes the paperwork almost as important as the maintenance,
because it's our responsibility to maintain the aircraft within those regulated guidelines

1063.66.text:
>>Stacy Sheard:
We have such a process involved in everything we do here, that nothing
will go out of here if it's not ready

1074.03.text:
If it doesn't pass every certain test in succession then the aircraft does not move forward.
It's quite safe.  My mother doesn't think so, but it is, very much so

1087.13.text:
>>Melissa Mathiasen:
There are aspects of being a test pilot that really require a special kind of person,
a special constitution, and special abilities both technical and professional

1098.13.text:
I think a test pilot is above all a professional, they aren't "hot-doggers" or "cowboys".
They are there to do a very specific job, as opposed to just going out to fly and have a good time

1112.56.text:
Not as opposed to other careers, but in aviation you need to become a professional,
and the reason for that is probably obvious

1122.55.text: everything you do someone's life depends on it, including your own

1127.36.text: You want to be precise about how you fly and responsible with your passengers

1132.25.text:
You want to be to responsible when turning wrenches on the aircraft
because people will be flying it

1137.66.text:
That teaches you professionalism and safety, it gives you pride about your work
and you actually get to see it fly, or fly it yourself

1145.56.text: That is what really drew me to aviation

1149.80.text:
>>Stacy Sheard:
To fly a helicopter, both of your hands, both of your feet and your mouth are working.

1159.10.text:
>>Amy Sargent:
The first time I started learning, I thought there was no way
I'd be able to do this, I was all over the place

1166.43.text:
>>Sjaan Shoepf:
I got in and the instructor took us up, he gave me one control, then two
and he said, "okay you have it" and I was convinced that I did

1175.56.text:
We drifted about 30 feet and he said, "Oh you don't have it"
so he took the controls back over

1183.33.text:
>>Amy Sargent:
The whole time I was training to be a helicopter pilot I was pregnant

1189.26.text:
>>Stacy Sheard:
I think it's just like everything else you learn, riding a bike, skateboard.
Everything takes a bit of coordination and time

1199.30.text:
>>Janie Foster:
Once it get through it all, it's well worth it.  It may not always seem that way
when your going through training

1206.26.text:
Then the difficult part after you get your inital training,
and if you work as a CFI building your hours, is to get a job

1214.83.text:
>>Sjaan Schoepf:
Once you get your first turbine job you got some experience,
then it opens up a little bit more

1221.53.text:
I think that's probably like any other career; the more experience you have
and the more skills you acquire, then more options become available

1231.16.text:
>>Stacy Sheard:
When I began working for Sikorsky, I had already done a lot of different jobs
in the civilian and military industry

1241.40.text:
I flew Huey's and Blackhawks in the army and I went from
flying infantry soliders around

1249.03.text:
and yelling at them when we land "get out, get out, get out!",
they have 3 seconds to get the heck out of the helicopter and we're gone

1256.73.text:
to moving to Las Vegas, and flying tours 
with someone's Grandma sitting next to me

1263.06.text:
When I was 5, I went to Germany to visit my grandmother and my aunt
was a flight attendant for Pan American at the time

1271.06.text:
She let me serve the hot towels and I thought, "I want to be a flight attendant!"
So from age 5 to 18, I knew that was what I wanted

1279.53.text:
So I applied to 2 major airlines, and they said "Sorry...",
and I said "What!?"  Then I said, "okay I'm going to be a pilot instead"

1288.83.text:
>>Amelia Earhart:
My full name is Amelia Earhart, and most people consider that
to be a little strange, so it draws a lot of attention

1296.30.text:
My family is distantly related to the "original" Amelia Earhart,
and I was named after her

1301.10.text:
My family doesn't really have any ties to aviation,
they just wanted to give me the name of a positive female role model

1308.63.text:
They wanted to give me a name that no one would ever forget,
but they let me find aviation on my own

1314.50.text:
>>Amy Sargent:
It's kind of funny because I didn't want to fly helicopters.
They made me and now I love it

1322.33.text:
My background is in airplanes; I started flying when I was 15 years old.
I've flown corporate, I've flown for "Life Link" Air Ambulance

1336.56.text:
I flew for commuters, I flew for a charter company, Sun Country Airlines
then I was on with Delta Airlines for a year

1345.23.text: But after "9/11" they furloughed 1,100 people, and I was one of them

1351.10.text:
When I found a job here at Mosquito Control as a part-time airplane pilot,
after awhile they created a position for a assistant chief pilot

1362.36.text:
So I started doing that, and then the chief pilot position opened up,
but they required the chief pilot to be dual rated

1372.00.text: So they trained me to be a helicopter pilot

1375.93.text:
>>Amelia Earhart:
I think that most people are at least vaguely interested in helicopters,
but not everyone is a good fit to work in one

1385.36.text:
If you get a job at a newsroom, usually you will need
to work your way up to the helicopter, that is how I did it

1391.56.text:
If you show interest, as a reporter, in just going up for a ride,
or shadowing one of the reporters that works in the helicopter

1401.33.text:
That's a great way to find out if you'd enjoy working in one,
and most people who work in helicopters will happily answer all of your questions

1409.00.text:
Do you want to see how I run the camera?  Come on out, I'll
spend 2 hours telling you about it, because we love what we do

1415.79.text:
>>Stacy Gandy:
There are many ways you can become an aircraft mechanic

1420.42.text:
You can go to school for 2 years, you can learn in the military,
but in order to get a civilian license you have submit that experience and take tests

1430.16.text:
Or you can work as an apprentice for an aircraft inspector for 3 years,
then that inspector can sign you off and you get your license

1436.76.text:
That is how I got mine. It might be the hardest way, but you definitely
know what your doing by the time you get your license

1444.15.text:
I actually have a degree in psychology and was going to law school,
then I took a summer job waxing World War II airplanes and I never left aviation

1456.06.text:
>>Caroline Caine:
The Whirly Girl Organization is quite unique, when you become a private
pilot they issue you a number and I became #587

1464.00.text:
I believe there are over 1,700 now internationally.
What's really nice is that if someone wants to forward their career in aviation

1473.26.text:
They can actually apply for scholarships, a few of my friends
have actually received scholarships of $5,000 and more

1481.23.text:
>>Heather Collins:
You certainly wouldn't want to invest a lot of time and money into something
and find out later that you get motion sick, and it just isn't for you

1488.20.text: and we have had that happen

1489.83.text:
So, if someone thinks they might be intersted in doing this,
they need to make sure that the nursing field or paramedic field is right for them

1500.20.text:
If that fits, then there are opprotunities to fly along with certain programs,
they allow you to get your feet wet and decide

1510.40.text:
Usually you'll know right away, yes this is for me,
or no this is not for me

1514.80.text:
>>Kris Kelly:
A lot of people start in fixed wing, and they go over and add
on the helicopter rating

1519.63.text:
I chose to do it all in helicopters, that was
where my heart and passion was

1525.83.text:
>>Sjaan Schoepf:
Basically you have to love to fly and you have to like helicopters

1531.50.text:
It's not as glamorous as everyone makes it out to be,
so if you're just looking for the image of being of a helicopter pilot

1540.33.text: it is a lot of work and it's still a job, so you really must enjoy it

1558.03.text:
But the second I pull into the driveway here at the airport,
and I see that helicopter sitting out there on the ramp

1563.16.text:
That's when I say, "alright let's do it again, let's see what's going
to happen today."  That is what is cool about this job, I never know

1570.20.text:
>>Caroline Caine:
I flew for New York Helicopters in 1988,
then I actually took some time off and now I'm back flying

1577.73.text:
When I first got hired here at Bristow,
I think the chief pilot had more confidence in me than I did at the time

1586.00.text:
I had not flown in 14 years. I decided to get married
and have a family and actually thought my career was done

1593.40.text:
My dad passed away 2 years ago and the shock of that reminded me that
life is short, and the only flying I was doing was in my dreams

1603.40.text:
I would look up and see the helicopters and tell my kids,
"That's an A Star or there's a Jet Ranger!" and they would say "what's that?"

1611.13.text: Finally I said, "I have to get back into this"

1616.35.text:
>>Melissa Mathiasen:
Your love for aviation can start at any age,
you can be impacted by something at any age

1622.70.text:
There are so many different jobs you can have in aviation;
you can be good at math, the arts, reading

1634.36.text: or if you really like computer science, you can find a home in aviation

1638.80.text:
So, if you have any interest at all, 
just go to a small airport and talk to some of the pilots around there

1647.56.text:
If you want to get started in any kind of industry, you need
to start networking; don't be shy, get out there and go for what you want to do

1655.96.text:
I never considered myself particularly special at anything
and look what I got to do

1662.03.text:
I really just encourage you, if you have any
interest at all, go check it out
